content_blocks.text: When a pair of lines meet each other at a point on a plane surface, we say that the lines intersect each other.
When two lines intersect each other and form four angles, labelled a, b, c and d, as in Fig. 5.2, then ∠a and ∠c are equal, and ∠b and ∠d are equal!
Draw two lines on a plain sheet of paper so that they intersect. Measure the four angles formed with a protractor.
Linear pairs are adjacent angles, like ∠a and ∠b, formed by two lines intersecting each other, which always add up to 180°.
Vertically opposite angles, like ∠b and ∠d, formed by two lines intersecting each other, are always equal to each other.
List all the linear pairs and vertically opposite angles you observe in Fig. 5.3:
Parallel lines are a pair of lines that lie on the same plane, and do not meet however far we extend them at both ends.
When two lines intersect and all four angles are equal, then each angle must be a right angle (90°).
For example, line segments FG and FH meet at the endpoint F at an angle 115.3°.
Perpendicular lines are a pair of lines which intersect each other at right angles (90°).
In Fig. 5.4, we can say that lines l and m are perpendicular to each other.
For example, line segments ST and UV are likely to meet if they are extended.
Parallel lines are often used in artwork and shading.
Which pairs of lines appear to be parallel in Fig. 5.6 below?
Note to the Teacher: It is important that the lines lie on the same plane.

In mathematics, we use an arrow mark (>) to show that a set of lines is parallel. If there is more than one set of parallel lines (as in Fig. 5. 9), the second set is shown with two arrow marks and so on.
Perpendicular lines are marked with a square angle between them.
Draw some lines perpendicular to the lines given on the dot paper in Fig. 5.10.
A transversal is a line that intersects two or more lines.
When a transversal intersects two lines, it forms eight angles with a maximum of four distinct angle measures.
Draw a pair of lines and a transversal such that they form two distinct angles.
Corresponding angles are pairs of angles that are formed by a transversal and are on the same side of the transversal.
For example, ∠1 and ∠5 are corresponding angles.

content_blocks.text: Fold the sheet horizontally in half. A new line is formed (see Fig. 5.7).
How many parallel lines do you see now? How does the new line segment relate to the vertical sides?
First Horizontal Fold: We will see three parallel lines. The new line segment is perpendicular to the vertical sides.
Subsequent Horizontal Folds: After one more horizontal fold, we will see a total of five parallel lines.
Vertical and Diagonal Folds: This new vertical line is perpendicular to the previous horizontal lines.

content_blocks.text: Tools required: Ruler, Set-squares (right-angled triangle), Pencil, eraser Steps: 1. Place the set square so that one side is along the line l. 2. Hold the ruler against the other side of the set square so that the ruler won’t move. 3. Slide the set square along the ruler until one side reaches point A. 4. Draw a line along the edge of the set square through point A. 5. This new line is parallel to line l and passes through point A.

Why are lines l and m parallel to each other? Ans: When we fold the paper, first we make line t perpendicular to l passing through A. Then we make another line m perpendicular to t through point A. Since lines l and m are perpendicular to t, so pair of corresponding angles are equal i.e. 900. Thus, l and m are parallel.
